comments.content: C is correct. And Port 2 appears without 0.0.0.0/0 because it has the same distance(10) as port 1. And 0.0.0.0 appears in Port 1, because it has the best(lowest) priority(20). I hope it helps.

choices.B: The port3 default route has the highest distance

questions.question_text: Which three statements about a flow-based antivirus profile are correct? (Choose three.)

choices.B: Traffic will be redirected to the transparent proxy and it will be allowed by proxy policy ID 3.
choices.D: Traffic will be redirected to the transparent proxy and it will be allowed by proxy policy ID 1.
choices.C: Traffic will not be redirected to the transparent proxy and it will be allowed by firewall policy ID 1.
choices.A: Traffic will be redirected to the transparent proxy and it will be denied by the proxy implicit deny policy.

discussion.content: A is correct as traffic is being sent to fortinet.com, which will not match any proxy policy as will be implicit denied.

comments.content:
Agreed. http-policy-redirect validates using the proxy policies. Since proxy policy 1 does not match fortinet.com and proxy policies 2 & 3 are disabled, the implicit proxy policy (deny) will deny the traffic.
https://kb.fortinet.com/kb/documentLink.do?externalID=FD40584

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Host regex match - Once created, the hostname address can be selected as a destination of a proxy policy. This means that a policy will only allow or block requests that match the regular expression.

So because both of the other proxy-policies are set to disable, only proxy-policy 1 is applicable.

https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortigate/7.0.1/administration-guide/720455/proxy-policy-addresses

Selected Answer: A
A é a verdadeira
By discarding the answers, the one that best satisfies the question is A
This sort of questions can be overwhelmed, however the key is read carefully each line, in this way you narrow the options. A is correct.

I don't get this question / answer either. Policy ID 3 has its status disabled and so shouldn't be passing traffic? I did spin this up in a lab and confirmed the configuration, but after disabling the allow all policy I could still reach the internet, which makes me think that policy id 1 was passing the traffic.

comments.content: In your lab you must have set your explicit proxy default firewall policy to accept. if you had it in deny it will block all http/https traffic but the matching EICAR.
In your lab you must have set your explicit proxy default firewall policy to accept. if you had it in deny it will block all traffic, but eicar
deny is default by the way, this not explicitly shown in any screenshot, so you must assume default, if default was accept, your answer would be true.

discussion.content: A - if traffic is redirected to web proxy then srcintf port3, dstintf port1 and this matches proxy policy 3 (fortinet.com -dst all) but is disabled so it is implicitly denied

comments.content: B not is correct. police id 3 ---> set status disable . i think is A correct.

discussion.content: B. Because in transparent Proxy, the client send requests to the web server and the web proxy intercepts the client's requests transparently.
Can someone explain please ? I don't get it

comments.content: because the proxy policy 2 & 3 has status set to disabled

discussion.content: why not D?

Selected Answer: AC
Options in CLI:
ping Use PING to test the link with the server.
tcp-echo Use TCP echo to test the link with the server.
udp-echo Use UDP echo to test the link with the server.
http Use HTTP-GET to test the link with the server.
https Use HTTPS-GET to test the link with the server.
twamp Use TWAMP to test the link with the server.
dns Use DNS query to test the link with the server.
tcp-connect Use a full TCP connection to test the link with the server.
ftp Use FTP to test the link with the server.

Options in GUI:
PING
HTTP
DNS

Selected Answer: AC
Fortigate Infrastructure 7.0 pg 81
